awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Development of resonators on high temperature piezoelectric materials for harsh environment sensor and oscillator applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to address the need for accurate devices capable of operating in extreme environments exceeding 250 °C. Many sensors have key components made of quartz, known for its high sensitivity, accuracy, and stability; but it cannot operate at temperatures exceeding 250 °C.  The applications requiring sensitive components operating at these high temperatures include interplanetary spacecraft, nuclear reactors, deep drilling, enhanced geothermal systems, and hypersonic aircrafts and missiles.  The proposed project will develop new sensors using advanced material technologies. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project aims to develop a novel resonator on piezoelectric materials optimized for performance at high temperature and pressure. The proposed dual-mode resonators are expected to exhibit much higher stability and accuracy.  They are also expected to have significantly less need for systemic recalibration. The three main objectives in this project are to optimize the cut angles of the piezoelectric material; develop wafer-level fabrication processes, for size and cost reduction; and to develop a wafer bonding process for eventual wafer-level packaging of the resonators. The effort address translation challenges in device structure, synthesis, modeling and optimization, wafer level fabrication and packaging, to make highly sensitive, accurate, small footprint, low-cost resonators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project was to address the need for accurate devices capable of operating in extreme environments exceeding 250 degrees C. Many sensors have key components made of quartz, known for its high sensitivity, accuracy, and stability; but it cannot operate at temperatures exceeding 250 degrees C. The applications requiring sensitive components operating at these high temperatures include interplanetary spacecraft, nuclear reactors, deep drilling, enhanced geothermal systems, industrial process control, and hypersonic aircrafts and missiles. The proposed project had the objective to develop resonators for sensors using high temperature piezoelectric material and advanced processing technologies.

The aim of the This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project was to develop a novel resonator on piezoelectric materials optimized for performance at high temperature and pressure. The proposed dual-mode resonators are expected to exhibit much higher stability and accuracy. They are also expected to have significantly less need for systemic recalibration. The three main objectives in this project were to optimize the cut angles of the piezoelectric material; develop wafer-level fabrication processes, for size and cost reduction; and to develop a wafer bonding process for eventual wafer-level packaging of the resonators. The effort addressed and de-risked some of the challenges in device structure, synthesis, modeling and optimization, wafer level fabrication and packaging, to make highly sensitive, accurate, small footprint, low-cost resonators.

The main accomplishments of the Phase I work involve three distinct areas:

  1. Most importantly, evaluating some promising orientations of high temperature piezoelectric material, Langasite, both from sensing and frequency controlling applications by fabricating devices and measuring them under high temperature conditions. Three different cuts of Langasite were used. The devices were tested up to a temperature of 650 degrees C.
  2. Process development efforts were conducted to fabricate devices on a wafer scale for the promising orientations of Langasite.  It is very important to note that each orientation of the single crystal poses significant challenges in process development due to high degree of anisotropy in the crystal structure. Different etch processes were studied and developed for different orientations of Langasite.
  3. Preliminary wafer scale package development effort with thermocompression bonding using a similar anisotropic material, quartz, was done for a proof-of-concept demonstration.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2022
Modified by: Kushal K Bhattacharjee
